title: Tesla says more than 50% of Model S and X drivers pay for FSD — and the percentage is up for other models too
description: Tesla Vice President of Vehicle Engineering Lars Moravy shared estimates of how many customers pay for Full Self-Driving.
content: Thanks in part to Jay Leno, we now have a better idea about how many Tesla drivers are using Full-Self Driving.Tesla Chief Designer Franz von Holzhausen and Vice President of Vehicle Engineering Lars Moravy appeared on an episode of "Jay Leno's Garage" released Monday. In it, Leno asked how often people use the driver-assistance software."You know, it's increasing a lot, like the take rate has gone up from single-digit percentages on all our cars to we're in the teens now," Moravy answered. "On S and X, it's over 50, 60%. And we have a lot of people that use it in these cars like on every drive, you know, you can get addicted to it really quick."Tesla released FSD in beta in the US in 2020 and to paying customers across North America two years later.FSD can follow your navigation route, change lanes, and make turns, although it has drawn scrutiny and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigations over some accidents, some of which were fatal. FSD still requires active supervision by a human driver at the wheel.New and existing Model S, Model 3, Model X, Model Y, and Cybertruck owners get a 30-day trial of FSD.Tesla has changed the price of FSD significantly over the years. In 2022, it rose in cost from $10,000 to $12,000 and then to $15,000. Most recently, the price was reduced from $12,000 to $8,000 in 2024. It costs $99 a month on a subscription basis.

keywords.name: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigations
Tesla Chief Designer Franz von Holzhausen

summary: Tesla has revealed that over 50% of its Model S and X drivers pay for Full-Self Driving (FSD), and this is increasing. The software, which can guide users through navigation, can also be used to navigate and make turns, but requires active supervision by a human. The price of FSD has fluctuated significantly over the years, rising from $10,000 to $12,000 and $15,000 in 2022, and recently was reduced to $8,000 by 2022.
shortSummary: Tesla's Full-Self Driving System (FSD) is used by over half of its Model S and X drivers, with usage increasing significantly, despite safety concerns.
argos_summary: Tesla reports that more than half of Model S and Model X owners now use Full‑Self Driving (FSD), up from single‑digit rates across the fleet to the teens. The company’s FSD beta, launched in 2020, offers navigation, lane changes and turns but still requires driver supervision and has faced NHTSA scrutiny over accidents. Tesla has adjusted FSD pricing over the years, most recently cutting the subscription from $12,000 to $8,000 in 2024 and offering a $99/month plan. The increased adoption signals growing confidence in the technology, though safety concerns remain.
